reviewText: "Shaolin Long Fist Kung Fu: Intermediate Sequences" with Nicholas C. Yang is a 446 minute program, contained on two disks, that focuses on traditional Shaolin Long Fist sequences.  These forms are basic training drills for a variety of martial attributes, including speed and strength.  Nicholas Yang teaches and demonstrates four traditional sequences: Yi Lu Mai Fu, Er Lu Mai Fu, Shi Zi Tang, and Xiao Hu Yan.Before the sequences, there is a guest appearance by Dr. Yang, Jwing-Ming.  Dr. Yang provides in lecture format, a history of the sequences Yi Lu Mai Fu, Er Lu Mai Fu, and Shi Zi Tang.  Using maps and charts with Chinese characters, he explains where they come from and provides background on the sequences.  This initial lecture is approximately seventeen minutes long.After Dr. Yang's lecture, the program gets into the instruction with Nicholas Yang.  Nicholas Yang is a very accomplished martial artist and he does a very good job of teaching to the camera.  Anyone who has read my reviews or seen my DVDs, knows that I prefer instructional programs that actually teach to the camera, rather than just a demonstration, with maybe a short voice over.  This DVD delivers.  Not only are the moves demonstrated with explanation, but also little extras are included as Nicholas teaches.  With that said, it will take several viewings and a lot of practice to make your moves seem as effortless as those you see in this program.This first things taught are basic steps and kicking that are fundamental to the forms that are coming.  Once four basic steps are taught and eleven basic kicks, the Yi Lu Mai Fu sequence is taught.  Please note, even though these are taught as "basics" that you need to know before the sequences, some, such as tornado kicks, will take a lot of practice to become proficient.The sequences are taught in sections, and Yang uses students to help him demonstrate and teach.  Along with the teaching are many useful tips to make you a better martial artist.  Then all the sections are put together for the entire sequence.  The final portion of the program includes martial applications from the sequence, and Yang points out that he is only providing an example, and not all applications or the only ones.  I also like his comments on the art being alive and not stale and stagnant as he advises people to analyze the art and themselves during their personal training.Then the program starts all over with the next form.  Basic stepping, Basic kicking, the sequence in sections, as a whole, and then martial applications.  This method is used for all four sequences taught in the program.I've come to expect a lot from YMAA DVDs, and this program is no exception.  There is a lot of information here.  It will take a long time to view and learn these forms, and then much longer to be able to perform them as seen on this DVD.  Obviously, we all know that the best way to learn a martial art is to learn in person from a qualified instructor.  However, for a variety of reasons, sometimes that is not possible.  This DVD is the next best thing to learn these Shaolin Long Fist forms.  They also make a great "at home" aid even if you are learning from an instructor.YMAA list this program as an intermediate, or level 2 skill level, and the program was designed to follow the Shaolin Long Fist Kung Fu Basic Sequences DVD and the Shaolin Kung Fu Fundamental Training DVD.  For anyone wanting to learn and study these specific forms, this is an outstanding DVD set.Reviewed by Alain Burrese, J.D., author of the Lock On Joint Locking Essentials series.
summary: Eight hours of excellent instruction and information!

reviewText: I agree with the other reviews about this DVD.  It is easy to understand and very thorough detailed information. Nicholas Yang and his father Dr. Yang are masterful teachers.  I learned a lot about Shaolin principles and proper technique. Very Highly recommended.
Title: N/A

reviewText: It has been said that you can not learn Kung Fu from books.But with a good DVD and book, one can learn a lot!Dr Yang has developed a good formula and format for training DVDs.And his son is carrying on the same formula and format.This makes for a very good instructional DVD.Both the forms and the applications of the moves are clearly shown and very well explained.The Shaolin Long Fist Kung Fu forms presented in this DVD are very energetic.They would do very well as an aerobics routine for for general health, in addition to learning Kung Fu.
summary: Excellent DVD on Shaolin Long Fist Kung Fu
Title: N/A

reviewText: If you are a fan of Dr Yang, Jwing-Ming then get ready for his son. His speech is easy to understand and movements are more refined for a modern world, this all American young Martial Artist has a lot to offer with this extensive video, solely designed for information, it is not very entertaining, meant for the martial artist who is ready to learn from a professors son. Get ready, this video is a Information smorgasbord on the semi advanced understand of Long Fist Kung Fu.Damian
summary: Nicholas c. Yang is a great teacher

reviewText: This is a wonderful intermediate workout! I had watched some trailers of it and thought that I could pick up the intermediate without doing the beginner series taught by the instructors dad.  I was wrong, I am waiting for the beginning one to come.  This one is still great! Highly Recommend!
summary: Awesome! But buy the beginner first!
Title: N/A

reviewText: Well if you didn't already know, the instructor in this very well executed two-disc DVD set is none other than Nicholas Yang, son of Dr. Jwing-Ming Yang and founder of YMAA. So with a pedigree like that, how can you expect this video to be anything short of fantastic. Well you simply can't, and it definitely is nothing short of fantastic. Although Nicholas doesn't have quite the charisma of his father, he is a very good instructor in his own right and is destined to become an even better instructor in the not too distant future.Now my expertise does not happen to be in Kung Fu, although there are many similarities between it and the arts that I have studied, especially when it comes down to the principles behind the techniques, which as the well versed martial artist knows is far more important than the techniques themselves.Mr. Yang goes over, in a very detailed and in-depth manner, all of the techniques and principles behind four of the more traditional Shaolin forms. From the subtleties of defense and attack, to the various techniques, Mr. Yang brilliantly describes all of the intricacies of each form in very impressive detail.Coming in at just shy of eight, yes you read that right, eight hours of instruction on this two-disc DVD, you definitely have more than got your money's worth buying this DVD.Shawn KovacichCreator of numerous books and DVD's.
summary: Like Father Like Son - Master and Student
Title: N/A

reviewText: Shaolin Long Fist Kung Fu, Intermediate Sequences, is presented by Nicholas Yang, President of YMAA International, and principle instructor at YMAA's Boston Headquarters.  Special guest appearances by Dr. Yang, Jwing-Ming offers a history discussion of each sequence prior to the introduction of the form.  This 2-DVD set builds upon the skills presented in YMAA's Shaolin Long Fist Kung Fu Basic Sequences DVD, and Shaolin Kung Fu Fundamental Training DVD.  Four traditional sequences are included in this video presentation:  Yi Lu Mai Fu, Er Lu Mai Fu, Shi Zi Tang, and Xiao Hu Yan.Each form is divided into sections for ease of practice and learning.  Interior jacket notes offer an easy-to-follow outline of the video structure so that the viewer/practitioner can quickly pick up where he or she left off.  Nicholas includes numerous martial applications to the movements and techniques contained within each form.  Even though this reviewer does not yet practice Long Fist, I found this component especially valuable as many of the martial applications are applicable and/or adaptable to other sequences or movements to forms that I have learned in over a decade of traditional martial arts study and practice.446 minutes of footage makes this not a sit-and-watch video of how-to kung fu.  This DVD clearly targets practitioners of Long Fist, particularly YMAA students.  However, any traditional Chinese martial arts practitioner will find benefit through deeper understanding of his or her own material, sequences, or techniques by taking away insights gained from the step-by-step analysis of the four sequences.With a recommened skill rating of 2 on a 3-level scale, this is not a beginner's video.  Prior to viewing this DVD, those interested should first be sure to begin with Shaolin Kung Fu Fundamental Training and Shaolin Long Fist Kung Fu Basic Sequences DVD, both excellent presentations available from YMAA publications directly, Amazon.com, or through your nearest book retailer.
summary: A very thorough and detailed instruction of traditional kung fu forms
Title: N/A

reviewText: Nicholas C. Yang gives excellent, balanced instruction in Shaolin Long Fist Kung Fu. He covers both the basic principles of rooting and centering and the martial applications of the form. I really like the way he shows the correct way of moving and also how not to do it. He clearly shows how leaning too far or sitting back too much will uproot your energy. He keeps it simple, not using more energy than necessary.Although my own practice is Yang Style Taijichuan, I found a great deal of applicable information in this instruction. Snakes, Fan through and parry, kicks are all beautiful in these sets. As a female in her 60's, the speed and flexibility of this training is something that will take me time to practice and attain. My 30ish daughter is a MMA kickboxer and she will pick up quickly on the techniques.A great DVD set for all levels practicing many forms of martial arts. As Sifu Yang says, there are many songs, compose different music all the time.
Title: N/A
